Any infinite set of naturals is denumerable.

type: (s : Set ℕ) → [inst : DecidablePred fun x => x ∈ s] → [inst : Infinite ↑s] → Denumerable ↑s
name: Nat.Subtype.denumerable
docString: Any infinite set of naturals is denumerable.

The set of prime natural numbers is infinite.

name: Nat.infinite_setOf_prime
docString: The set of prime natural numbers is infinite.

This is Euclid's theorem on the infinitude of primes. The theorem states that for every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p` is greater than or equal to `n`. In other words, there are infinitely many prime numbers, and for any given natural number, there will always be a prime number that is greater than or equal to that number.

name: Nat.exists_infinite_primes
docString: This is Euclid's theorem on the infinitude of primes. The theorem states that for every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p` is greater than or equal to `n`. In other words, there are infinitely many prime numbers, and for any given natural number, there will always be a prime number that is greater than or equal to that number.

For every irrational real number `ξ`, there exists an infinite sequence of rational numbers `{q_n}` such that `|ξ - q_n| < 1 / (denominator(q_n))^2` for all `n`.

statement:
theorem Real.infinite_rat_abs_sub_lt_one_div_den_sq_of_irrational :
    ∀ {ξ : ℝ}, Irrational ξ → {q | |ξ - ↑q| < 1 / ↑q.den ^ 2}.Infinite := by sorry
name: Real.infinite_rat_abs_sub_lt_one_div_den_sq_of_irrational
docString:
If `ξ` is an irrational real number, then there are infinitely many good
rational approximations to `ξ`.
description: This theorem states that if `ξ` is an irrational real number, then there exist infinitely many rational numbers `q` such that the absolute difference between `ξ` and `q` is less than the reciprocal of the square of the denominator of `q`. In simpler terms, no matter how irrational a number `ξ` is, we can always find an infinite number of rational numbers that are extremely close to it—where "closeness" is defined relative to the size of the rational number's denominator.
concise-description: For every irrational real number `ξ`, there exists an infinite sequence of rational numbers `{q_n}` such that `|ξ - q_n| < 1 / (denominator(q_n))^2` for all `n`.

A sum of numbers is infinite iff one of them is infinite

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_1} {M : Type u_4} [inst : AddCommMonoid M] {s : Finset ι} {f : ι → WithTop M},
  (Finset.sum s fun i => f i) = ⊤ ↔ ∃ i ∈ s, f i = ⊤
name: WithTop.sum_eq_top_iff
docString: A sum of numbers is infinite iff one of them is infinite

For any infinite set of natural numbers and any positive natural number, there exist distinct elements with the same remainder when divided by that number.

type: ∀ {s : Set ℕ}, s.Infinite → ∀ {k : ℕ}, 0 < k → ∃ m ∈ s, ∃ n ∈ s, m < n ∧ k.ModEq m n
name: Nat.exists_lt_modEq_of_infinite
docString: For any infinite set of natural numbers and any positive natural number, there exist distinct elements with the same remainder when divided by that number.

This theorem states that the ordinal number one is less than omega. In other words, the ordinal corresponding to the number one is smaller than the first infinite ordinal, denoted as omega. Omega is defined as the order type of the set of natural numbers, which means it corresponds to the concept of "countable infinity" in set theory.

name: Ordinal.one_lt_omega
docString: This theorem states that the ordinal number one is less than omega. In other words, the ordinal corresponding to the number one is smaller than the first infinite ordinal, denoted as omega. Omega is defined as the order type of the set of natural numbers, which means it corresponds to the concept of "countable infinity" in set theory.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} {M : Matroid α} [self : Matroid.InfiniteRk M], ∃ B, M.Base B ∧ Set.Infinite B
name: Matroid.InfiniteRk.exists_infinite_base

The set of prime numbers is unbounded.

name: Nat.not_bddAbove_setOf_prime
docString: The set of prime numbers is unbounded.

This theorem states that if `ξ` is an irrational real number, then there exist infinitely many rational numbers `q` such that the absolute difference between `ξ` and `q` is less than the reciprocal of the square of the denominator of `q`. In simpler terms, no matter how irrational a number `ξ` is, we can always find an infinite number of rational numbers that are extremely close to it—where "closeness" is defined relative to the size of the rational number's denominator.

name: Real.infinite_rat_abs_sub_lt_one_div_den_sq_of_irrational
docString: This theorem states that if `ξ` is an irrational real number, then there exist infinitely many rational numbers `q` such that the absolute difference between `ξ` and `q` is less than the reciprocal of the square of the denominator of `q`. In simpler terms, no matter how irrational a number `ξ` is, we can always find an infinite number of rational numbers that are extremely close to it—where "closeness" is defined relative to the size of the rational number's denominator.

A product of finite numbers is still finite

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_1} {R : Type u_8} [inst : CommMonoidWithZero R] [inst_1 : NoZeroDivisors R] [inst_2 : Nontrivial R]
  [inst_3 : DecidableEq R] [inst_4 : LT R] {s : Finset ι} {f : ι → WithTop R},
  (∀ i ∈ s, f i ≠ ⊤) → (Finset.prod s fun i => f i) < ⊤
name: WithTop.prod_lt_top
docString: A product of finite numbers is still finite

For every finite set of natural numbers, there exists a natural number that is an upper bound for the set.

type: ∀ (s : Finset ℕ), ∃ n, s ⊆ Finset.range n
name: Finset.exists_nat_subset_range
docString: For every finite set of natural numbers, there exists a natural number that is an upper bound for the set.

The theorem `Ordinal.one_add_omega` states that if we add 1 to the first infinite ordinal, which we denote as `Ordinal.omega` and is defined as the order type of the natural numbers ℕ, the result is still `Ordinal.omega`. This captures the essence of infinity in ordinal arithmetic: adding a finite number (in this case 1) to an infinite ordinal does not change the infinite ordinal.

name: Ordinal.one_add_omega
docString: The theorem `Ordinal.one_add_omega` states that if we add 1 to the first infinite ordinal, which we denote as `Ordinal.omega` and is defined as the order type of the natural numbers ℕ, the result is still `Ordinal.omega`. This captures the essence of infinity in ordinal arithmetic: adding a finite number (in this case 1) to an infinite ordinal does not change the infinite ordinal.

The infinite monadic lazy list of natural numbers.

type: {m : Type → Type} → [inst : Monad m] → MLList m ℕ
name: MLList.range
docString: The infinite monadic lazy list of natural numbers.

Infinite ordinals that are cardinals are unbounded.

type: Set.Unbounded (fun x x_1 => x < x_1) {b | Cardinal.ord (Ordinal.card b) = b ∧ Ordinal.omega ≤ b}
name: Cardinal.ord_card_unbounded'
docString: Infinite ordinals that are cardinals are unbounded.

An infinite encodable type is denumerable.

type: (α : Type u_3) → [inst : Encodable α] → [inst : Infinite α] → Denumerable α
name: Denumerable.ofEncodableOfInfinite
docString: An infinite encodable type is denumerable.

Infinitely many natural numbers are equal to `d` mod `n`.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, n ≠ 0 → ∀ (d : ℕ), ∃ᶠ (m : ℕ) in Filter.atTop, m ≡ d [MOD n]
name: Nat.frequently_modEq
docString: Infinitely many natural numbers are equal to `d` mod `n`.
